text: hi I'm Melissa Clark from the dining
section
it's that brisket time of year again the
Jewish holidays are upon us are you
going to make brisket I'll bet if you do
you go to the butcher shop and you just
get brisket right well there are
actually two kinds of brisket and I'm
going to show you the difference this
over here is an entire brisket it weighs
about 14 pounds usually when you go to
the butcher you get a piece of it maybe
five or six pounds for a holiday dinner
when the butcher cuts up a piece of
brisket what he does is he looks for
this part over here this is the navel
this part that comes up and then he just
cuts right behind it
separating it into two pieces the first
cut is the leaner piece of brisket you
can see it in the muscle fibers do you
see how they're close together there's
no fat in between them there's a little
bit of fat on top there's some fat in
the middle and what happens when you
braise this meat is that it cooks
together instead of falling apart and
separating and if it's not done exactly
right it can be kind of tough and dry as
you can see in the second cut of meat
which is also called the devil cut the
fibers are separated by little veins of
fat that fat causes the meat to just
fall apart when you cook it it adds
flavor it has juiciness and succulents I
think it's just an easier piece of meat
not to mess up but the choice is yours
this Rosh Hashanah if you like your meat
on the leader side get the first cut if
you want it a little bit fattier and
richer ask for the second cut or if
you're feeding a lot of people buy the
whole entire brisket and braise it in
one big piece that's how chefs cook it
that's how they make it
the choice is yours
